awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Impact of Substellar Objects on Late Stellar Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently, planets and brown dwarfs (objects intermediate in size between planets and stars) have been discovered around very old stars that have ejected most of their material, leaving a small hot star known as a "subdwarf B" (sdB). Prior to ejecting material, the sdB stars were large red giant stars. Thus, their planets and brown dwarfs must have been engulfed as the red giant star expanded. The PI plans to use small telescopes to search for more of these sdB stars and determine whether they have companion planets or brown dwarfs. He will determine the masses of the stars and their companions, and compare the new data set with theories for how stars change near the end of their lifetimes. He will establish an integrated research and education program that will, first, teach university students to observe with robotic telescopes. The students will then teach high school teachers and students to use the telescopes to discover and analyze sdB stars. This will strengthen the students' interest and active participation in STEM research.

Finding the companion masses in a large number of post-common envelope sdB binaries will provide the first robust tests of models involving red giant-engulfed companion interactions. The lower mass limits resulting from this work will help constrain model parameters relating to tidal effects and angular momentum conservation. Determination of orbital periods, eccentricities, and component masses will provide constraints on hot subdwarf formation models and improve understanding of this stage of stellar evolution. The PI, through collaborations with other astronomers, has access to Evryscope data, SKYNET, and the SOAR/Goodman telescopes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background

Hot subdwarf B (sdB) stars are core helium-fusing objects with half the mass of the Sun and one-fifth its size. They formed from red giants that were stripped of their outer atmospheres due to binary interactions with a nearby companion. A large fraction of sdBs are in tight orbits with red dwarfs (dM) or brown dwarfs (BD) and have periods on the order of hours. They evolved through a common envelope (CE) phase in which both stars orbited inside the shared atmosphere of the red giant. Since we still see the companions today, we conclude they survived red giant engulfment and were responsible for the formation of the hot subdwarf. A large study of sdB+dM/BD binaries is one of the best avenues for determining the influence stellar and substellar objects can have on late stellar evolution, and their likelihood of surviving it. The primary objectives of this project were to (i) increase the sample of known, post-common envelope sdB+dM/BD binaries by discovering new ones; (ii) obtain follow-up data on new systems; (iii) model the data to derive masses; and (iv) analyze the resulting period and mass distributions.

Intellectual Merit

We discovered more than 150 new eclipsing and non-eclipsing post common envelope sdB+dM/BD binaries using photometry from OGLE, ATLAS, and TESS (Schaffenroth et al. 2019; Barlow et al. 2022, 2024). We also quadrupled the number of known eclipsing systems---the ones most conducive to modeling. Standout sdB+dM/BD binaries discovered include the first totally eclipsing system (Corcoran et al. 2021), the shortest-period system (Lopez et al., in prep), and several with substellar companions (Schaffenroth et al. 2022). 

We found no binaries with orbital periods shorter than ~1 hour (Schaffenroth et al. 2022). Below this, the companions either merged with the red giant sdB progenitor or evaporated. We also found no evidence of planets orbiting hot subdwarfs. However, we have confirmed that substellar brown dwarfs can influence stellar evolution by stripping the outer atmosphere off a red giant; they also survive this interaction. Our derived mass distribution reveals that hot subdwarfs with dM/BD companions are more massive than those with white dwarf companions.

Non-eclipsing sdB+dM binaries have generally been ignored in the literature since the inclination is difficult to constrain. We found that light curves from TESS do permit us to solve for the inclination and masses in the systems (Schaffenroth et al. 2022). The inclination angle affects the shape of the reflection effect, and these small effects can lead to robust modeling solutions if the data are of high enough quality. We also used TESS light curves to detect a slight asymmetry in the reflection effect of sdB+dM/BD binaries, which we attribute to relativistic beaming (Barlow et al. 2024). 

Finally, we developed a technique for identifying candidate variable stars using photometry from Gaia. Since the reported Gaia DR2 flux errors were empirically determined from the scatter of multiple brightness measurements, variable sources should have anomalously large uncertainties. We identified more than 500 hot subdwarfs that had large flux errors and collected high-cadence TESS light curves of them. We find that this method is effective, with more than 95% of our candidates turning out to be variables (Barlow et al. 2022). We also worked with collaborators to apply this method to white dwarfs (Guidry et al. 2021).

Broader Impacts

Eight undergraduates worked on this project and were supported by this grant. They learned how to (i) write and submit observing proposals; (ii) download data using MAST; (iii) write Python code to read, manipulate, and analyze time-series photometry; (iv) present results at local, national, and international conferences; (v) measure radial velocities from low- and medium-resolution spectra; and (vi) observe on-site and remotely with professional telescopes.

We created a new "service learning" astronomy course at High Point University, in which students were required to contribute 25 service hours to our outreach project called Learning Astronomy through Service and Research. We teamed up with Big Brothers Big Sisters (BBBS) for this project. Each undergraduate was paired with one BBBS Big/Little pair and helped them carry out simple observing projects over the semester using the robotic Skynet telescopes. 

Funds from this grant were also used to produce the first opera conceived for a planetarium, "Galaxies In Her Eyes." The opera tells the story of a little girl named Eden who dreams of going to Mars one day, despite being told by others she can't. In a series of dream-like sequences, she runs across Ada Lovelace, Katherine Johnson, and Annie Jump Cannon, all of whom encourage her to keep chasing her dreams. We consulted with the librettist on the science in the story, programmed visuals for the planetarium dome, and generally worked with the composer, librettist, conductor, and director to bring the performance to life in the Culp Planetarium at High Point University in April 2022.
